;;T;<小>;HE VIDEO;弗朗西斯斯科特基大桥倒塌的镜头令人震惊。 3月26日凌晨1时30分左右，一艘集装箱船撞上它，这座1.6英里（2.6公里）长的建筑的中心部分塌陷到下面的帕塔普斯科河中，导致人员和车辆落入水中。当时，桥上正在修复坑洼的工人。水下无人机、声纳和红外工具显示多辆车辆淹没在河中。 “你永远不会想到你会看到......基桥像那样倒塌，”巴尔的摩市长布兰登·斯科特告诉记者。 “它看起来像是动作片中的东西。”

;; ;

;马里兰州州长宣布进入紧急状态。截至周二晚上，潜水员正在搜寻六人。美国土木工程师学会结构工程研究所 (ASCE) 主席杰里·哈贾 (Jerry Hajjar) 表示，除了人员伤亡之外，迫在眉睫的问题还涉及这场灾难的原因和后果，这是美国几十年来最严重的灾难之一。 ;）。 ;FBI; 表示恐怖主义不太可能是幕后黑手。

;

;这艘 300 米长的船根据网络安全和基础设施安全局的一份非机密报告，;Dali; 号正从巴尔的摩港前往斯里兰卡科伦坡，当时“失去了推进力”。据报道，船员通知官员可能会发生桥梁碰撞。目击者称，船的灯光在撞击前闪烁。当地人在半夜听到了雷鸣般的隆隆声。 “房子开始摇晃，”海港对面的马里兰州 Locust Point 居民赛勒斯·吉尔伯特 (Cyrus Gilbert) 说道。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这座桥的结构本来应该是健全的。 ;ASCE; 的一份报告在 2020 年为马里兰州的桥梁授予了 ;B; 评级，并为港口授予了 ;B-; 评级。邓迪大学科学与工程学院土木工程和造船建筑专家 Masoud Hayatdavoodi 说： “毫无疑问，桥梁会因柱子受到冲击而倒塌。”

;

;乔·拜登总统承诺将为此买单尽快重建桥梁。但对这座城市的经济影响已经显现。港口交通已关闭，直至另行通知，这在港口以外引起了涟漪。该港口支持超过 15,000 个直接就业岗位，并且大约有 140,000 个就业岗位以某种方式与之相关。这包括从亚马逊司机到当地干洗店的一切。该港口不仅在巴尔的摩，而且在马里兰州都有着巨大的足迹。马里兰州陶森大学区域经济研究所的达里斯·伊拉尼 (Dariys Irani) 表示，仅港口关闭一项就可能造成每天约 50 美元的经济活动损失。

;

;清理期间，端口活动可能会减慢或暂停。该港口是美国供应链的重要一环。超过 50 家海运承运人每年进行近 1,800 次访问。这在汽车领域尤其重要。 2023 年，其私人和公共码头处理了近 85 万辆汽车和轻型卡车，是美国港口中处理量最多的。 2023年，该港口在农业和建筑机械以及进口糖和石膏的吞吐量方面也排名全国第一，煤炭出口排名全国第二。

;

;如果另一个港口因某种原因（例如，由于天气、劳资纠纷或网络攻击）出现问题，美国经济可能会遭受严重损失。但就目前而言，全国影响可能有限。其他港口，如纽约-新泽西和弗吉尼亚港口，应该能够弥补这一空缺。评级机构穆迪首席经济学家马克赞迪表示，国民经济将<小>;好;，但巴尔的摩将感受到集体钱包的痛苦。通勤者和卡车司机也将面临干扰。去年，该桥每天为 34,000 辆商业和客运车辆提供服务，约占该地区交通量的 15%。

;

;巴尔的摩港长期以来一直是美国韧性的象征。 1812 年抗英战争期间，美国人成功保卫了巴尔的摩港的麦克亨利堡，弗朗西斯·斯科特·基 (Francis Scott Key) 在他的 19 世纪诗歌中将这一事件永垂不朽，该诗后来成为美国国歌。这场悲剧将使城市和港口有时间实施升级，而当港口活跃时，这会变得更加困难。在了解了灾难的全部范围并适当哀悼逝去的生命后，巴尔的摩可能会出现更好的桥梁和港口。 ;■;

;;;;在呼吁中国;时，西方政府有时喜欢站在一起。 3月25日至26日，美国、英国和新西兰联合打击中国网络间谍活动。美国检察官指责中国的网络间谍多年来针对西方的广泛目标发动了一场行动，其中包括批评中国共产党的人。英国副首相奥利弗·道登表示，中国表现出“针对我们集体民主国家的持续敌对活动模式”。新西兰指责中国与国家有关的黑客对该国议会发起网络攻击。

;

;美国和英国都对涉嫌的中国黑客实施了制裁一组中国黑客的幌子公司，他们称之为 ;APT;31。他们还对该组织的两名涉嫌成员实施了制裁，而美国则对他们和另外五名男子提出了刑事指控。这些行动不太可能对中国的努力产生太大影响。字母;APT;代表“高级持续威胁”。这是涉及潜伏在目标网络中未被发现的攻击的技术术语。这些话也恰好传达了西方对中国网络攻击的悲观看法。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;发现网络入侵（更不用说确定责任人）可能需要时间。西方三个国家揭露的事件大多发生在两三年前。道登先生告​​诉议会，“中国政府附属行为者”已于 2021 年侵入了选举委员会的电子邮件和文件共享系统。这一违规行为于 2023 年 8 月首次公开宣布，当时官员透露，直到 2022 年 10 月才发现可疑活动——黑客入侵一年多后。肇事者可以访问英国选民的地址。道登没有具体说明参与此次袭击的组织。但他表示，;APT;31 “几乎可以肯定”是 2021 年针对 ;MP; 电子邮件帐户的“侦察活动”的幕后黑手。其中大多数目标都是著名的批评者中国。

;

;向纽约法院提交的针对 ;APT;31 七名成员的起诉书提供了丰富的细节该团队的活动。这份长达 27 页的文件称，该组织隶属于中国主要间谍机构——国家安全部 (;MSS;) 湖北省分局。其幌子公司武汉晓睿智科技有限公司Technology 成立于 2010 年左右。据称，从那时起，该组织就针对美国和其他地方的数千名政客、学者、记者和民主活动人士。根据该文件，它还针对被视为“国家重要性”的美国行业的个人和公司，包括与国防、<小>;IT;和电信相关的行业。

;

;英国淡化了其发现的中国黑客攻击的影响——没有选举受到影响，并且;议员;的电子邮件的目标是“被议会的网络安全措施阻止”。新西兰表示，另一个与 ;MSS; 相关的组织，名为 ;APT;40，参与了 2021 年针对其议会的网络攻击，但这并未导致信息泄露敏感信息。然而，美国起诉书称，;APT;31 的活动“已导致数百万美国人的工作和个人电子邮件帐户、云存储帐户和电话记录遭到确认和潜在的泄露，其中至少包括可能会发布一些信息来支持针对民主进程和机构的恶意影响”。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;网络安全公司 Recorded Future 的 Mark Kelly 表示，他的公司据了解，中国有大约 50 个黑客组织，其中包括为 ;MSS; 或中国人民解放军工作的私营公司。毫无疑问还有更多。凯利先生将中国的网络间谍活动描述为“数量级”，其规模比俄罗斯或朝鲜的网络间谍活动还要大。

;

;起诉书显示，他们的权力下放令人惊讶。英国情报机构军情六处前副局长奈杰尔·英克斯特 (Nigel Inkster) 表示，其中一些人专门从事世界不同地区的间谍活动。他说，他们有相当大的余地可以按照自己的意愿行事：“我什至不确定是否存在任何正式的政治许可机制。”他们的大部分工作都分包给私营公司。上个月，I-Soon 等公司的大量在线文件显示该公司代表多个政府机构参与了大规模网络窥探活动。

;

;西方的焦虑越来越明显。一月份，<小>;联邦调查局;负责人克里斯托弗·雷 (Christopher Wray) 声称，中国政府支持的黑客数量与联邦调查局网络人员的数量“至少为 50 比 1”。他表示，中国的目标不仅是政治和军事：“中国的黑客正在美国的基础设施上进行部署，准备在中国决定发动攻击的时候对美国公民和社区造成严重破坏并造成现实伤害。”< /p>;

;中国外交官驳回了此类指控。中国驻伦敦大使馆发言人称英国的指控是“捏造和恶意诽谤”。如果西方希望通过点名、羞辱和制裁来劝阻中国间谍，那么它很可能会失望。正如英克斯特先生所说：“我认为北京不再特别担心手指伸进收银台会带来的政治后果。” ;■;

; ; a ; a ; ;十年前; xi jinping受欢迎到德国的杜伊斯堡鲁尔谷。他称赞该地区是中国投资的中心；迎接一列从重庆出发，经俄罗斯，前往欧洲工业带，用了两周时间的列车；并欣赏了传统采矿歌曲的管弦乐演奏。最近，另一位中国人抵达德国却受到冷遇。 2月，一艘名为Byd Explorer 1号; Byd Explorer的船，由中国电动车辆（; byd ;），一辆中国电动车辆（; ev ;）公司制造的电动汽车。正如该船的名字所暗示的那样，它很可能是许多人中的第一个。这一点毫不奇怪，这引起了人们对德国神圣汽车制造商的未来的担忧。

;

;中国正在搅动汽车，因为其领导者的现金和贷款是借出现金和贷款高科技行业试图恢复该国的垂死经济。其制造业贸易顺差已创历史新高，并且还将继续上升。因此，欧洲领导人担心先进、廉价的中国商品涌入。 3月5日，欧盟委员会决定有足够的证据宣布，中国对其; ev ;制造商提供了不公平的补贴，为引入关税铺平了道路。该委员会主席乌苏拉·冯德莱恩(Ursula von der Leyen)警告中国不要在绿色科技方面“竞相抄底”。英国已开始对该国的挖掘机进行调查。法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙将于五月接待习近平。根据外交官的说法，他将在交易中传达“坚定的信息”。

;从巴西到印度的国家正在转向中国的出口。然而，由于欧洲大陆长期以来以贸易为核心的增长模式，它们对欧洲构成了特殊的威胁。根据; IMF ;，欧洲是世界上最开放的贸易和投资的地区（请参阅图1）。在; eu ;商品和服务的贸易中，; gdp ;的44％，几乎是美国的两倍。作为一个基于规则的集团，; eu ;不愿通过建立贸易保护主义障碍而公然违反贸易规则。英国也有支持自由贸易的历史。

;

;新的中国震惊到达了一个可怕的时刻。欧洲工业仍在应对弗拉基米尔·普京入侵乌克兰造成的能源冲击，这次入侵正值各国领导人试图加速绿色转型之际开始。天然气价格通常为每兆瓦时 20 欧元（22 美元）左右，到 2022 年将飙升至 300 欧元以上，导致电价飙升（见图 2）。新冠疫情后的反弹演变成通货膨胀和能源危机。欧洲中央银行（; ecb ;）被迫将利率提高到4％，在已经削弱的经济中达到需求。

;在大流行和能源危机期间的财政大规模自此以来，此后一直给予裁员。德国的严格赤字限制迫使该国今年削减了，在2025年将有更多的削减。法国刚刚宣布，其2023年的赤字占; GDP ;的5.5％，远高于预测。它已经拉动了其财政部长布鲁诺·勒·梅尔（Bruno Le Maire）称之为“紧急制动器”，削减了100亿欧元的支出，以使财政政策重回正轨。

; ; ;;L;;ittle more; than a month ago Senegal was in the midst of a constitutional crisis. ;Macky Sall;, the outgoing president, had tried to delay elections by ten months.他最受欢迎的竞争对手入狱并被取消竞选资格。安全部队殴打并逮捕抗议者。 Many feared that a country widely seen as a bulwark of stability in a region once again beset by ;coups; and overstaying presidents might be the next domino to fall.

;

;Yet the doomsayers were proved wrong. On March 24th voters turned out in unusually large numbers to give their verdict on Mr Sall's 12 chequered years in office. In polls that passed almost entirely without incident, they delivered a comfortable majority to Bassirou Diomaye Faye, an anti-corruption crusader who was freed from prison less than two weeks before the vote as part of a last-minute amnesty deal.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Within a few hours of the first results, the ruling party's candidate, Amadou Ba, graciously accepted defeat. Mr Sall, who did much to weaken Senegal's institutions, and who last year mulled standing for a constitutionally barred third term, hailed the peaceful conclusion to the vote “a victory for Senegalese democracy.”

;

;At 44, Mr Faye will be Africa's youngest elected leader. He joins a burgeoning club of millennial men who have recently taken charge in several west African countries—Guinea, Mali and, a bit further afield, Niger and Burkina Faso—at least partly on the back of popular dissatisfaction with greying leaders and predatory elites. Mr Faye is unique among this group in having come to power through the ballot box rather than by a coup. Yet Senegal's president-elect typifies the same broad populist reaction to regional insecurity, chronic unemployment and the perceived meddling of France, the former colonial power.

;

;Mr Faye, who has never held elected office, declared his victory a vote for “rupture” over continuity. He has promised to curb graft and clip the powers of the presidency. Before the election he took the unusual step of publishing his net worth in the name of transparency. More controversially, he suggested leaving the ;CFA; franc, a regional currency backed by France, and renegotiating oil and gas licences awarded by his predecessor to foreign investors.

;

;Behind Mr Faye lurks the figure of Ousmane Sonko, his closest ally and by far Senegal's most popular opposition leader. A charismatic firebrand, Mr Sonko rattles the country's political and business classes; in an interview with ;The Economist; last year Mr Sall accused him of inciting violence. (Indeed, the opposition leader did once tell his followers: “If you force open the homes [of those in power] you will find billions there.”)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Sonko was arrested in 2021 and charged with rape.尽管这项指控被无罪释放，但他仍被判犯有“青少年腐败”罪，即对 21 岁以下人士的不道德行为。他还因指控政府部长腐败而被判诽谤罪。他表示这些指控是出于政治动机，并否认有不当行为。 But his conviction made him ineligible to stand for president, even after he was freed from prison alongside Mr Faye, who promptly replaced him as their party's presidential candidate.

;

;The pair are both former tax inspectors who have worked with one another for years. They are said to be joined at the hip: Mr Faye is reported to have nicknamed his son “Ousmane” in his friend's honour. After leaving prison, they campaigned under the slogan “Diomaye is Sonko”. Mr Faye, the more buttoned-up of the pair, has yet to reveal whether his friend will hold an official government post. But even if he does not, the divisive Mr Sonko will doubtless wield weighty influence behind the scenes. “They will work together in tandem,” says Alioune Tine of Afrikajom Centre, a think-tank in Dakar. “This is their joint project.”

;

;The exact details of this project remain vague. In his first speech as president-elect Mr Faye promised to govern with “humility”. In the days before the vote he had sought to placate foreign investors, declaring himself the strongest guarantor of their security among all the contenders for the presidency, while watering down his pledge to replace the ;CFA; franc with a new national currency. (Though widely seen in the region as a colonial-era relic, the common currency helps to contain inflation and monetary volatility.) Perhaps seeking to put to bed fears that he and Mr Sonko would cut ties with France and open the door to Russia, the incoming president also stressed in his inaugural speech that Senegal would remain a “safe and reliable ally” for all “respectful” foreign partners.

;

;;A;;t the Siemens Gamesa; factory in Hull, workers are busy making 180 turbine blades for ;a wind farm off the coast; of Aberdeenshire in Scotland.每颗都长 108 米，是一颗巨大的剑形牙齿，专门用来切割空气。 A core of fibreglass is layered with epoxy resin, balsa wood and plastic to produce “just the right combination of flexibility and stiffness”, says Andy Sykes, the project director.

;

;Once ready, the blades will be laid horizontally on boats in the Humber estuary to head north for installation. The waters off Britain's east coast are dotted with windmills that supplied almost a sixth of the country's electricity last year. Two-thirds of these turbines have blades made in Hull.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Politicians of all stripes point to the Siemens factory as a model. On a visit in 2021, Rishi Sunak, then chancellor, said it pointed to the critical role of domestic green industries. Sir Keir Starmer, the Labour Party's leader, has bold ambitions of Britain becoming a “green-growth superpower”, spurred by a boom in manufacturing jobs. Ed Miliband, the shadow energy secretary, whose constituency is nearby, wants to “rebuild Britain's industrial strength”.

;

;That is improbable.英国是一个开放的、以服务业为基础的经济体。与德国、韩国或美国部分地区不同，它的工业规模很小。只有 7% 的工作岗位来自制造业。 “Politicians hate saying it but Britain is a services superpower…we're not going to turn ourselves into Germany,” says Torsten Bell, head of the Resolution Foundation, a think-tank, and a former adviser to Mr Miliband. Boosting services in second-tier cities, Mr Bell argues, is a more plausible plan for economic revival.

;

;But green industries could still play a big role in helping Britain lower its carbon emissions and in improving the prospects of its former industrial heartlands. Britain has some advantages in high-value manufacturing and clean-technology innovation, according to a study by Anna Valero of the London School of Economics. The country has excellent universities. It has ready access to the North Sea. It could expand in areas such as offshore wind and carbon capture and storage (;CCS;), where carbon produced in industrial processes is isolated and pumped underground.

;

;A tour of the Humber gives a sense of the possibilities and the hurdles. Its geography is unusual, combining a deep-water channel, some 14km wide near the mouth, with vast tracts of flat land perfect for factories. In the 18th century the estuary propelled the expansion of the Yorkshire coalfields by making water-borne freight easier. In the 20th century it expanded as a hub for North Sea oil and gas. Along with Teesside, the Humber's banks became the most industrially intensive part of Britain. By the early 1980s there were 1,600 factories on Humberside, employing almost a third of the local workforce.

;;
;;
;

;The Humber now aspires to be the “green-energy estuary”.除了叶片工厂之外，该地区还吸引了一系列绿色项目（见地图）。格里姆斯比是欧洲最繁忙的海上风电服务港口。 Orsted, a Danish state-owned developer, is erecting the world's biggest offshore wind farm, one of many off the coast. There are plans to produce hydrogen from natural gas at Saltend with ;CCS;; the port of Immingham is being upgraded to allow for hydrogen to be exported.

;

;Head inland to Keadby and ;SSE;, a British company, has won approval to build one of the world's first gas-fired power stations with ;CCS;.在塞尔比，德拉克斯正试图在生物质方面做同样的事情。 In both cases the plan is for the captured carbon to be piped back under the North Sea.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It makes sense to develop ;CCS; in Britain's dirtiest region.建设储存氢或碳封存所需的基础设施成本高昂，但一旦完成，应该会吸引更多投资。 To make “green” hydrogen, which is produced from water using a renewables-powered electrolyser, it helps to be near sources of cheap renewable energy.

;

;A green-energy boom could bring more jobs to the region. The blade factory, which the government helped to lure in 2016 with tax incentives, employs around 1,500 people, many of whom have come through a nearby technical college. Making blades is essentially “craft-based work”, says Mr Sykes. One reason Siemens chose Hull is that it was already the British capital of caravan manufacturing—another “craft based around composites with lots of transferable skills”.

;

;But as much as the factory has been a boon for the city, it may not be a model for Britain.涡轮机制造价值中只有大约五分之一来自叶片。赫尔大学工程学教授詹姆斯·吉尔伯特指出，机舱（包含所有电子设备的中央枢纽）的容量是其两倍。西门子在德国库克斯港就是这样做的。 Britain ought to be aiming to attract investment in the higher-value end of the supply chain.

;

;Spend time on the Humber and you can see why that will be hard. Hull has a good university with strengths in robotics and manufacturing. But like many former industrial areas, it feels neglected and cut off. Over the past 40 years manufacturing's share of jobs in the region has fallen by almost half. Philip Larkin said he liked living there because it was “so far from everywhere else”. What pleases misanthropic poets is less alluring to investors. Visiting executives are put on a minibus at Manchester airport because rail services across the Pennines are so unreliable, says Ian Kelly of Hull and Humber Chamber of Commerce. Isolation makes it hard to retain young graduates.

;

;Much depends on policies made in Westminster. The Humber must compete for green investments with the likes of Lower Saxony, in Germany, and Midtjylland, in Denmark. But according to Andrew Elmes of Siemens Energy, Britain has much less settled climate policies than Denmark, Germany or France.

;

;Mr Miliband remains keen for Britain to have its own national champion to rival the likes of Orsted. The Humber, he says, “can absolutely be at the vanguard of Britain winning the [global] race.” But there is a tension between attracting foreign investment and domesticating the supply chain. As with turbine blades, success will rest on having the right amount of flexibility. ;■;

;;E;;VERY YEAR; on April 7th Paul Kagame, Rwanda's president, commemorates the start of the most abominable event of the late 20th century, the Rwandan ;genocide;. Over 100 days in 1994 masses of the majority Hutu population slaughtered hundreds of thousands of their countrymen, mostly from the minority Tutsi group. In these annual speeches Mr Kagame offers glimpses of why he is Africa's most polarising leader. In one breath there is the official narrative: Rwanda is now a miracle of peace, unity and prosperity—a beacon of progress lit from the embers of the genocide. In the next there are hints of the more sinister figure his critics decry, for instance in his disdain for those who challenge him. They also point out his brutal repression and his warmongering in neighbouring Congo.

;

;Ahead of the 30th anniversary of the genocide some observers in Kigali, the capital, hope that Mr Kagame will use this year's event to move beyond the question of whether Rwanda is Africa's Singapore or Africa's North Korea. About two-thirds of Rwanda's population are under 30. Might, some diplomats and businessmen speculate, the 66-year-old president speak of the next 30 years, loosen the grip of his authoritarian state and suggest when he will step aside?

;

;That is unlikely. In the “land of a thousand hills” only one man can have the moral high ground. On July 15th Mr Kagame will almost certainly be re-elected as president with a margin that would make even Vladimir Putin blush, in a ballot neither free nor fair. Having won 98% of votes in a constitutional referendum in 2015 that still allows him to run for two more terms of office lasting until 2034, he is going nowhere.

;To assess Rwanda today one can look at Mr Kagame's policies in three distinct places: at home, in the wider Great Lakes region , and in the rest of the world. Across them a picture emerges of some reform and reconciliation, with a lot of repression and realpolitik. Central to Mr Kagame's domestic agenda is state-enforced brainwashing. At ;ingando; (“solidarity”) camps and in prisons, an official narrative is drummed into the population. It is a story that emphasises a national Rwandan identity over ethnic ones and that does not mention any of the crimes committed by Mr Kagame's party, the Rwandan Patriotic Front (;RPF;).

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;For the government, the case for top-down reconciliation is obvious given that perpetrators live cheek by jowl with the families of victims. Has it worked? A state-sponsored “reconciliation barometer” shows that nearly 100% of Rwandans respond positively to questions about whether they are tolerant, trusting and united. Phil Clark of the School of Oriental and African Studies at the University of London, has written that “most Rwandans… have chosen to get on with life rather than settle old scores”.

;

;Other researchers argue that in Rwanda reconciliation is often superficial. Susan Thomson of Colgate University has described “everyday resistance” to government schemes. This includes people keeping silent or even laughing during community meetings, and passing critical messages clandestinely at vegetable markets.

;

;Though it is impossible to see into the hearts of ordinary Rwandans, one can see the repression that has come with reconciliation. Expansive laws banning “divisionism” and genocide denial are used against dissidents. A system in which neighbours spy on one another keeps close tabs on villagers. Journalists and opposition politicians have been imprisoned and some have died in mysterious circumstances. Opponents of the regime outside the country have been harassed and, in some cases, killed.

;

;Rwanda prefers it when visitors focus on Kigali's clean streets, its gleaming convention centre, the lack of petty corruption and its mountain gorillas. Western diplomats praise Rwanda's effective use of aid, which adds up to the equivalent of around 75% of government spending. Such is the interest from other African officials that there is now a dedicated agency explaining how they can use Rwanda's methods. It is a sign of what Ken Opalo, a Kenyan academic, calls “Rwanda envy”.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Some of that is justified. ;GDP; grew by more than 8% a year on average from 1995 to 2022. Life expectancy increased from 49 years to 66 between 2001 and 2021. Child mortality fell by 77%.

;

;Yet there may be less to Rwanda's success than meets the eye. Several researchers have credibly suggested that official measures of poverty underestimate its true extent. Others have questioned official data on agricultural yields. Just 2% of Rwandans have fridges, a symbol of African middle-class life. That is well below the rate in other countries such as Ethiopia (6%) and Tanzania (10%) that have similar income levels, according to the Global Data Lab based at Radboud University in the Netherlands.

;

;In private many Rwandans complain about big gaps between the rich and poor. The country has a higher Gini coefficient, a benchmark for income inequality, than regional peers. A sense that the gains from growth are heavily skewed to a narrow elite could be socially dangerous. One study suggests that Tutsis, who make up 10-15% of the population, hold 80% of top jobs in government and state-owned firms such as Crystal Ventures, which is run by the ;RPF;, and Horizon, which is run by the army. Some scholars praise these firms for investing in the economy, though they can also deter investors by stifling competition.

;

;Yet Mr Kagame's ambitions have never been limited by his country's borders. In the 1980s he and other Tutsi exiles in Uganda helped Yoweri Museveni take power in that country. In the early 1990s the ;RPF; went to war against the then Hutu-led regime in Rwanda, and in 1994 they marched on Kigali to end the genocide, which was sparked when a plane carrying Juvenal Habyarimana, Rwanda's president, was shot down. In 1997 Mr Kagame and Mr Museveni together toppled Mobutu Sese Soku, Congo's dictator for three decades, after he gave sanctuary to Rwandan army and militia leaders who had participated in the genocide. When the man they replaced him with, Laurent Kabila, proved less than pliant, Rwanda invaded again, instigating a war that led to the loss of 1m-5m lives, mostly from hunger and disease.

;

;Rwanda, which seems to export more minerals than it mines at home, has retained a strong presence in resource-rich regions of eastern Congo. According to the ;UN,; it supports an armed group known as ;M;23, which is accused of murder and rape and is close to capturing the regional capital, Goma, increasing tension between Congo and Rwanda. “War could break out at any time,” worries a Western diplomat.

;

;Rwanda's sympathisers argue that its actions in eastern Congo are about self-defence and the protection of Tutsis. The Rwandan government points out that there are links between the Congolese army and a group known as ;FDLR;, which traces its origins to the Hutu genocidaires who fled in 1994. Yet there is more to Rwanda's meddling. The latest spasm of violence by ;M;23 followed Congo's moves to sideline Rwanda by inviting Burundian and Uganda troops into the country, and by drawing closer to Kenya's economic orbit. Michela Wrong, a journalist, wrote last year that: “Kagame has long believed in his right to be ;incontournable; [“unavoidable”] not only in Rwanda but also in the region, on the continent, and even in the global arena.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Some of the early aid to Rwanda was motivated by Western guilt at having failed to intervene to stop the genocide; some because Rwanda was proof that aid to Africa could actually work. Increasingly, though, it is Mr Kagame's transactional realpolitik that ensures the support of Western countries. Britain, for instance, wants to send asylum seekers there. Some in Rwanda's government regret the deal because they see it as tarnishing its brand, but there have been benefits. Britain has agreed to pay £370m ($470m) for the “partnership” by 2026, about ten times more than its annual aid contributions to the country, with more cash if asylum-seekers ever arrive. That contrasts with Britain's response in 2012 to an ;M;23 offensive, when it cut aid to Rwanda.

;

;France, too, is cosying up to Mr Kagame. For years relations were strained because a French judge accused the ;RPF ;of shooting down the plane carrying Habyarimana, whose regime Paris supported. Emmanuel Macron, who in 2021 in Kigali asked for forgiveness for France's role during the genocide, has repaired relations. The ;EU; is funding Rwanda's deployment against jihadists in Mozambique, near where Total, a French energy giant, is building a huge gas project. In February, to the ire of Congo, the bloc announced an agreement to boost mineral exports from Rwanda.

;

;America has taken a tougher stance. It has imposed sanctions on a Rwandan general for his alleged role in supporting ;M;23 and has suspended military aid. But America remains Rwanda's largest donor and it is reluctant to alienate Mr Kagame, an ally with a strong army that he is willing to send to unstable parts of Africa. Rwanda's leader also knows his way around Washington; in February he wooed Congressmen at a prayer breakfast. (By contrast, a South African delegation turned up during recess and struggled to meet anyone.)

;

;Indeed, Rwanda has seemingly managed to stay friends with those across several political divides. China has built most of Rwanda's major roads and sells it weaponry. Mr Kagame has praised Russia's role in Africa—yet will be one of a few African countries to soon host a new Ukrainian embassy. Rwanda expressed sympathy with Israel after the massacre by Hamas on October 7th, but has also sent baby formula to Gaza. Qatar is a major investor in Rwanda but this month Kigali welcomed a delegation from the its rival, the United Arab Emirates. “Kagame understands that, ultimately, diplomacy is all about interests,” says a diplomat.

;

;When Rwanda's leader speaks on April 7th there will be many foreign dignitaries in attendance. When he wins re-election in July, few of them will speak out. There is a grim logic to such reticence: Mr Kagame will be calling the shots for at least another decade. But as his fourth decade in charge of Rwanda begins, the outside world may want to ponder a question. How stable can Rwanda really be, if it depends on the rule of just one man? ;■;

;;T;<小>;两周;之后，枪手;袭击了莫斯科附近的克洛库斯市政厅造成至少 137 人死亡，美国情报部门警告称，“极端分子”“迫在眉睫”计划袭击该市的大型活动。 3 月 7 日，俄罗斯安全部门表示，他们挫败了圣战组织伊斯兰国 (;IS;) 对莫斯科一座犹太教堂的袭击。因此，在番红花城袭击发生数小时后，该组织声称对此事负责，也就不足为奇了。 3 月 25 日，四名据称来自塔吉克斯坦的嫌疑人出庭。美国官员认为他们是伊斯兰国呼罗珊省（;ISKP;）的一部分。这是什么组织，它会构成什么威胁？

;

;;ISKP; 是 ; 的中亚分支>;IS;，该组织于 2014 年在伊拉克和叙利亚建立了“哈里发国”。（;IS;;到 2018 年失去了其控制的大部分土地;。其他几个分支也很活跃在 ;非洲;和其他地方。）呼罗珊是一个历史区域，包括伊朗、阿富汗和其他中亚国家的部分地区（参见地图）。 ;ISKP; 主要驻扎在阿富汗北部和东部，是塔利班不共戴天的敌人，塔利班是一个伊斯兰组织，在 2021 年 8 月美军撤离后重新控制了该国。;ISKP; >; 将塔利班描述为与美国签署协议并配合美国撤军的出卖者。它还经常在信息组中批评塔吉克斯坦独裁者埃莫马利·拉赫蒙（Emomali Rahmon），他是俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京的盟友，因为他禁止 ;伊斯兰教信仰的对外表现;。

;;
;;
;

;;ISKP; 似乎成立于 2014 年。它吸引了心怀不满的巴基斯坦塔利班成员以及阿富汗成员，后者的政权已被美国击溃。到 2003 年，该组织追随逊尼派伊斯兰教，并以对非信徒和其他伊斯兰团体更加不宽容而自豪，其中包括什叶派伊斯兰教的追随者，什叶派伊斯兰教是继逊尼派之后的第二大信仰分支。它声称对 2019 年至 2021 年间发生的多起阿富汗清真寺、葬礼和学校袭击事件负责。在美国从该国撤军期间，它进行了;自杀-喀布尔机场发生爆炸;，造成 100 多人死亡，其中包括 13 名美国士兵。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;自 2022 年 7 月以来，阿富汗统治者多次下令对该组织的藏身处进行突袭。 The number of successful attacks by ;ISKP; in the country has fallen.专家表示，袭击可能促使;ISKP;把目光投向更远的地方。 2022年，该组织声称向塔吉克斯坦和乌兹别克斯坦的军事设施发射了火箭。 2024 年 1 月，它发动了伊朗革命后历史上最严重的恐怖袭击，在 2020 年被美国无人机暗杀的军事指挥官卡西姆·苏莱马尼 (Qassem Soleimani) 的纪念活动中造成 100 多人死亡。

;

;;ISKP;的招募策略发生了变化。据信，大约有 4,000 名来自中亚的武装分子加入了伊拉克和叙利亚的<小>;伊斯兰国;。哈里发政权被推翻后，许多人返回家园。 ;ISKP;正在尝试招募他们。该集团的媒体运营现在使用该地区的多种语言，从波斯语到乌兹别克语。 2022 年，它在 Telegram 上推出了塔吉克语网络，通过该网络宣扬其推翻拉赫蒙先生的意图。

;

;番红花城袭击是最新证据表明，;ISKP; 正在将注意力转向中亚以外的地区。一月份，两名武装分子袭击了伊斯坦布尔的一座教堂，造成一人死亡。德国官员表示，他们最近挫败了一次有计划的袭击。在莫斯科暴行发生之前，;ISKP; 频道上出现了一系列反俄罗斯信息。普京与塔利班和拉赫蒙的关系使他的国家成为攻击目标。 ;ISKP;的宣传还引用了他在高加索地区穆斯林占多数的车臣地区发动的残酷战争、他对叙利亚针对伊斯兰国的干预以及苏联在 20 世纪 80 年代入侵阿富汗，作为俄罗斯敌视穆斯林的证据。 .

;

;俄罗斯情报机构可能因乌克兰战争而过于分心，无法阻止此次袭击。分析人士警告称，西方机构也面临压力。克洛库斯市政厅的大屠杀痛苦地提醒我们，<小>;IS;所构成的威胁依然存在。 ;■;
